| Item | Key points |

## 1. Why “recommended daily intake” (AI) is expressed the way it is  

Fluoride is **not an essential nutrient** (the body can survive without it), so health agencies do **not set a Dietary Reference Intake (DRI) or Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)** the way they do for vitamins or minerals.  
Instead they publish an **Adequate Intake (AI)** – the amount that, on average, provides **the dental‑caries‑preventive benefit seen in the population while staying comfortably below the level at which adverse effects (mainly dental fluorosis) appear**.

### 1.1 How the AI is derived  

| Step | What the scientists do | Key data sources |
|------|------------------------|------------------|
| **a. Identify the “optimal” fluoride exposure for dental health** | Look at large community‑water‑fluoridation trials and epidemiologic surveys that compare tooth‑decay rates at different fluoride intakes. The “sweet‑spot” is the intake that yields the greatest reduction in dental caries **without a clinically relevant rise in fluorosis**. | U.S. Public‑Health Service (USPHS) “Optimal Fluoride Concentration” reports (1970s‑1990s); Cochrane reviews of water fluoridation; WHO “Guidelines for Drinking‑Water Quality”. |
| **b. Translate that exposure into a daily dose** | Convert the optimal intake (usually expressed as **mg F⁻ day⁻¹ per kilogram of body weight**) into an absolute daily amount for an “average adult”. The conversion uses the **average water consumption** (≈ 1.5 L day⁻¹ for adults in the U.S.) and the **target water‑fluoride concentration** (0.7 mg/L). | National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data on water consumption; EPA water‑usage surveys. |
| **c. Add a safety margin** | Because the data on non‑dental outcomes (e.g., skeletal fluorosis, neurodevelopment) are still being refined, agencies add a **factor of safety** (often 2‑ to 3‑fold) to ensure the AI stays well below any plausible toxic threshold. | EPA **Reference Dose (RfD)** of 0.04 mg kg⁻¹ day⁻¹, derived from the No‑Observed‑Adverse‑Effect Level (NOAEL) for skeletal fluorosis in animal studies, divided by an uncertainty factor of 10. |
| **d. Publish the AI** | The **Institute of Medicine (IOM, now the National Academy of Medicine)** released the AI in 2001: 3 mg day⁻¹ for adult men, 4 mg day⁻¹ for adult women (the higher value for women reflects lower average body weight). | IOM (2001). *Dietary Reference Intakes for Calcium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Vitamin D, and Fluoride*. |

> **Bottom line:** The AI is a *population‑level estimate* of the amount of fluoride that most people will get from water, food, and incidental ingestion of dental products, and that is sufficient to keep cavities low while keeping fluorosis risk minimal.
